bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William E. Deeks, September 8, 1924

div1.p: Carter comments on how to minimize the malaria problem. He recommends an article to Deeks.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William E. Deeks, September 8, 1924
div1.opener:
PLEASE RETURN TO FILE.
Miscl
Deeks-
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 8, 1924.
Dr. W. E. Deeks, General Manager,
Medical Department, United Fruit Company,
17 Battery Place, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Deeks:
div1.p:
This Memorandum is written by me, but is what LePrince and
myself agreed on as being as efficacious in lessening your malaria
as any method, or combination of methods, which were practicable.
We lay some stress on the factors determining the amount of malaria
caused by the different breeding places of Anopheles, as a considera-
tion of these factors, especially the species of Anopheles produced,
should determine the precedence of control of one breeding place
over another as you cannot Control ally must select the most injurious ones.

I am sending a carbon to LePrince so that he can add: strike out
or change anything in it he wishes. I will, of course, transmit his
reply to yourself.

There is an excellent article by Yorke in the Transactions of
the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene for March 20th. and
May 15, 1924: Vol. XVIII: Nos. 1 and 2. It is a long article, but I
think you should read pages 19: 25 and 28.

LowYorke makes a, to me, astounding statement on Page? 25 that malaria maybe more menable to treatment in a syphiditic more and what
Balfour says in the last paragraph of Page 27 is also interesting.

It was a most delightful trip and I cannot enough thank your-
self and the United Fruit Company therefor.

With best remembrances to you and yours from Laura and myself
myself
and trusting to see you in Washington in the not too distant Future
div1.closer:
Very truly your friend (Signed) H. R. Carter. Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Enclosure.
